narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A basic introduction to the Indonesian language and culture. We learned how to introduce ourselves and our hometowns. We also learned how to ask basic questions of who, what, how, why, etc. Weekly mini-lectures on the Indonesian culture also helped us understand some interesting facts about Indonesia.
I gained a lot of knowledge in speaking in Indonesian including how to speak, translate, and Indonesian culture.
I learned basic Indonesian! I can have a simple conversation in this language now!
I learned how about a different culture and how to speak a different language
I had no knowledge about the Indonesian language, history, and the country itself. I was able to communicate in indonesian while also being able to understand basic knowledge about the country.
Learned the basics of Indonesian language and culture.
Basic language skills
Learned how to communicate in indonesian
I learned the basics of Indonesian and how to hold conversation at an elementary level.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Pak Indriyo made the course really fun and engaging with his enthusiasm and patience. The weekly mini-culture lectures and weekly speaking practice sessions also really helped support our language study. I think I would hope to have more small scale assignments to keep up with retention and memorization of vocabulary/grammar. Not necessarily for a big grade but small assignments like make five sentences using this week's unit would help just to know if we are learning/applying our materials correctly and consistently.
A strength of this course was how slow the instructor went to make sure everyone understands the course work. A weakness of this course is that the work wasn't graded for a while.

The class schedule and structure changed constantly. It would have been nice for the schedule of practice conversations to remain constant so we didn't have to take time to re-schedule each student's practice conversations each week. That said, the instructor took immense effort to incorporate student feedback into the course design throughout the semester, even at the very end. When I suggested that one-on-one discussions with native Indonesian speakers was the best way to learn the language, he found several former Indonesian instructors residing in Indonesia and organized longer discussion opportunities for students. The course also introduced us to many exciting aspects of Indonesian culture. We learned about coffee, dance, sites to travel to, traditional music, food, and much more.
This course was an overall gem in my opionion. I thought the format with ngobrols and constant opportunity to speak freely really helped my learning of the language
I was strong at understanding and writing the language. However, I struggled with formulating sentences and speaking the language.
Virtually, Pak Indriyo provided a spark for myself especially since the class is early in the morning. He makes the class exciting and not a total dread.
Phenomenal teaching and lectures were very interesting.
Great course
The strengths of this class was it was very entertaining and I always wanted to go to class today

The strengths of this course was the willingness of both the professor and TA to help their students learn. One weakness however could be the slight lack of organization in terms of assigning coursework, receiving feedback on homework or assignments, but this was somewhat alleviated by the weekly discussion sections.
I wouldve liked to have more group conversation in Indonesian, as opposed to one on one.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The half-week synchronous and half-week asynchronous was really helpful and appreciated, especially since our class was early in the morning. Plus Pak Indriyo was really connected, as was Kak Ganis, whenever we reached out with questions, etc.
Everything succeeded because everything was accessible on Canvas and nothing was hard to do.

The instructor's internet wasn't always the best quality, and his screen was often blurry. So we had to download materials ourselves and keep multiple screens open simultaneously to clearly read the notes he was going over with us in class. Otherwise, the Zoom sessions were smooth and effective. Except for the difficulty of having the class synchronously repeat phrases after the teacher--a common practice in language instruction. This never worked with Zoom! I thought the TA's use of Jamboard and dropbox was helpful for arranging class activities.

I felt it was easier to engage because the class was so small and I had my camera on. He had us engage by having sentences translated or something along those lines. He also put us in breakout rooms which I thought was beneficial. The course itself was run very well, but the only complaint I have is that we never received a grade for the course until the final grade so I couldn't see how I was doing or what I could improve on.
I think that the files on the weekly modules were successful. We were able to look at what each lesson was built around for most days.
All succeeded.
Good
Communication to its students could be improved
I liked the asynchronous activities on Thursday and Friday, and I dont think there is anything that can be done differently considering the fact that COVID restricts many activities.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are looking to learn more about a culture and want to pick-up a new language I definitely recommend learning bahasa Indonesia. This was one of my favorite classes at Yale without a doubt. I also really appreciated Pak Indriyo's and Kak Ganis' kindness and patience with students as we slowly picked up the language. Also Pak Indriyo takes student suggestions and feedback really well; his responsiveness is unique to my experience at Yale when it comes to tailoring the classroom and learning objectives to student interests and learning speeds.
Yes because it's a very interesting class and I learned a lot this semester.
Of course! Indonesian is fun, and even though people say it is easy, it is hard and intellectually stimulating if you are serious about learning it well.
Yes, I would. I liked the class a lot because it got me out of my comfort zone and was very interesting. Pak Indriyo was also awesome and would recommend him to anyone.
I would recommend since it is a course that not many of those who take it thought they would take and that circumstance allows it to open their eyes to something else.
Yes. Awesome class and teaching.
Yes
Yes! I would absolutely recommend this course! Pak Indriyo is the most wonderful instructor ever! Hes so engaging and positive! This course is so much fun and interesting as well!
Yes I loved this course. It was very fun and taught me a lot about the culture of Indonesia
Yes, for anyone wanting to get into another language, Indonesian is a fantastic option with amazing teachers.
